body: I just tried to use different server for testing: wss://echo.websocket.org/test and I had exactly the same issue with failing sends exactly 60 seconds after establishing a connection

There were a few WS bug fixes that went into curl 8.14.0. I have no idea if
they would affect this problem, but it's probably worth trying the latest
libcurl before debugging this too much more.

I just tried version 8.16.0, same problem. 
After some debugging, it appears the reason of the problem is `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT_MS`. Whatever value I set with `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT_MS` determines when `curl_easy_send` would fail with 55 (`CURLE_SEND_ERROR`) while `WSAGetLastError()` would return `WSAEWOULDBLOCK`.
Looks like when connect only is used, this timer doesn't get reset internally when using winssl.

If I enable `CURLOPT_VERBOSE` I get this log when calling `curl_easy_send`:
```
CURLINFO_TEXT(000002393A1790D0): schannel: timed out sending data (bytes sent: 0)
```

There is a [check for timeout](https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/e5950b2d372ac4f15f6b348227f462d4c3c4d37a/lib/vtls/schannel.c#L1977) in `schannel_send`, while `ossl_send` doesn't have such checks. Not sure if send should have that check, seems like the check should happen before or after doing ssl encryption in common code not specific to some ssl provider.

schannel_send is different from ossl_send and it appears both are functioning as intended, unless I misunderstand? The error code is a little confusing. schannel_send returns result CURLE_OPERATION_TIMEDOUT but then curl_easy_send converts that into CURLE_SEND_ERROR. I'm not sure why it works that way. IMO it makes more sense to pass on the original CURLE code

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/11b991232fbcaa88e2b1faecac224416b0001e35/lib/easy.c#L1298-L1304


But still your operation timed out as expected, no?

edit; On second thought I don't think we can guarantee timeouts for connect only handles. Interested in what others think about this.

> schannel_send is different from ossl_send

`schannel_send` is the code used for processing send requests when schannel is used, `ossl_send` I'd expect to do similar task when openssl is used. That's why I find it suspicious that `schannel_send` checks some timers that `ossl_send` doesn't check. Also, I think these timers shouldn't be checked in ssl-specific code (unless schannel code takes over the socket and pipes data directly to it).

> But still your operation timed out as expected, no?

No, nothing should time out. I use it for websocket and after connection is established that timeout for request shouldn't be used at all. Basically, my webscoket becomes broken after running correctly for CURLOPT_TIMEOUT_MS milliseconds (any attempts to send data fail).

As a temporary fix/workaround when connection is established for websocket use I set `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT_MS` to 0 to disable it. Still, I believe it's a bug in schannel code.

> On second thought I don't think we can guarantee timeouts for connect only handles. Interested in what others think about this.

I agree. Only `CURLOPT_CONNECTTIMEOUT_MS` should be relevant imo. `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT_MS` perhaps shouldn't even be used for connect only sockets.

schannel_send has different send behavior. If you set a transfer timeout then libcurl can timeout the transfer so it would seem schannel_send is working correctly. But for that matter so is ossl_send, even though it doesn't have similar code to timeout. I don't know that we have a rule about this for transfers marked as connect only and I don't recall it ever having come up before.

I could try to check non-ssl websock and see if it times out the same way as ssl one. In any case, there is a bug for sure: when it "times out" incoming messages still keep coming, it only fails to send outgoing messages.
**Update:** non-ssl has no problem and doesn't timeout. Looks like some bad code in ossl. It makes no sense to handle timeouts in encryption code. It should just encrypt and pass it on to next the layer. timeouts should be handled in common code, there is nothing "specific" in ossl vs other ssl implementations or non-ssl code

> **Update:** non-ssl has no problem and doesn't timeout. Looks like some bad code in ossl. It makes no sense to handle timeouts in encryption code. It should just encrypt and pass it on to next the layer. timeouts should be handled in common code, there is nothing "specific" in ossl vs other ssl implementations or non-ssl code

That's your opinion and not the way it works. We can put timeout checks anywhere if necessary. There is a reason why we have a timeout check in parts of schannel because it has to block waiting for write in some cases, which should happen instantly but it's not guaranteed. It is not simply encrypting the data it is also sending it. For various reasons schannel records must be sent in whole. Other backends vary. They all may send differently. There's no separate internal encrypt state from send.

@bagder @icing Not sure what to do here but we should have some consistency. If a timeout is set we either timeout for all or for none. IMO this is not an ssl issue, that just demonstrates the problem. We could support some sort of "relaxed" timeout in all cases, like in other words we wait for the application to call for easy_send/recv and check timeouts then, but there's no guarantee of timeout until the application calls that function.

Or we could always return timeleft 0 after connect for connect only handles, like this

~~~diff
diff --git a/lib/connect.c b/lib/connect.c
index efe6248..6451703 100644
--- a/lib/connect.c
+++ b/lib/connect.c
@@ -126,6 +126,11 @@ timediff_t Curl_timeleft(struct Curl_easy *data,
   if(data->set.timeout <= 0 && !duringconnect)
     return 0; /* no timeout in place or checked, return "no limit" */
 
+  /* connect_only handles are turned over to the application after connecting
+     and therefore that application must manage timeouts for consistency. */
+  if(data->set.connect_only && !duringconnect)
+    return 0;
+
   if(!nowp) {
     now = curlx_now();
     nowp = &now;
~~~

Or similar maybe we could zero out the timeout variable right before [marking](https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/curl-8_16_0/lib/multi.c#L2085-L2090) the transfer as done internally (ie connect only handle has connected).

etc
I am currently trying to find why the transfer has a `timeout` set at all. AFAICT, we do not set a default?

> I am currently trying to find why the transfer has a `timeout` set at all. AFAICT, we do not set a default?

in my code I had it set to 50 seconds. By default it's 0 afaik

> > I am currently trying to find why the transfer has a `timeout` set at all. AFAICT, we do not set a default?
> 
> in my code I had it set to 50 seconds. By default it's 0 afaik

And if you do not set it, everything works?

> And if you do not set it, everything works?

Yes. I updated my code to simply set it to 0 when connection succeeded in connect-only mode:

> As a temporary fix/workaround when connection is established for websocket use I set CURLOPT_TIMEOUT_MS to 0 to disable it. Still, I believe it's a bug in schannel code.

I tried it to run for a couple of minutes and it was ok. So, I think it's 0 by default, or some large value that I didn't have patience to wait for (and I didn't try to check in debugger default value)

> Or similar maybe we could zero out the timeout variable right before [marking](https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/curl-8_16_0/lib/multi.c#L2085-L2090) the transfer as done internally (ie connect only handle has connected).

if ppl reuse that handle after that, some may think that timeouts they set should stick

If I understood you correctly, there is no problem if you do not set the timeout. And it you set a timeout, it will eventually bite, as it should.

Is there anything more to clarify to close this issue?

> If I understood you correctly, there is no problem if you do not set the timeout. And it you set a timeout, it will eventually bite, as it should.
> 
> Is there anything more to clarify to close this issue?

Well there is a problem. It's unclear what happens on connect-only style connections when a transfer timeout is set. libcurl's connection part in the transfer is over when it returns control to the application, or in other words the application manages the transfer. However the application can then call parts of libcurl that may (or may not) evaluate the remaining transfer time. See my [earlier post](https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/18991#issuecomment-3395689740).

> And it you set a timeout, it will eventually bite, as it should.

No. If I set the timeout there is no problem observed in general, **only when it's ssl** connection with **schannel**. If ssl with openssl - there is no problem, if it's non-ssl connection - also no problem. The issue specifically with schannel

> Well there is a problem. It's unclear what happens on connect-only style connections when a transfer timeout is set. libcurl's connection part in the transfer is over when it returns control to the application, or in other words the application manages the transfer. However the application can then call parts of libcurl that may (or may not) evaluate the remaining transfer time. See my [earlier post](https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/18991#issuecomment-3395689740).

For a connect-only transfer, only `CURLOPT_CONNECT_TIMEOUT` is relevant. And that will not interfere later. There is no need to set `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT` for this, afaict.

The question then seems to be, how `curl_easy_send()` should work. Since there is potential blocking IO with regard to Schannel (at least that, we have similar blocks in other, older protocols), it seems a use case to have some sort of timeout control for `curl_easy_send()`.

We could take the stance that a `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT` applies to each invocation of  `curl_easy_send()` or `curl_easy_recv()` *starting in each call again*. Maybe that could be made working?

> > And it you set a timeout, it will eventually bite, as it should.
> 
> No. If I set the timeout there is no problem observed in general, **only when it's ssl** connection with **schannel**. If ssl with openssl - there is no problem, if it's non-ssl connection - also no problem. The issue specifically with schannel

Schannel is the only place you see the effect of `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT`. There are other places in curl where this may also happen. The general questions to clarify is:

*What does an application expect to happen, setting `CURLOPT_TIMEOUT` on a connect-only transfer that it plans to use `curl_easy_send/recv()` on?*

Maybe you could state from your point of view, what is it you expect? Why do you set it?
